Solution to Question 1:
This is a modern compound microscope, and the condenser is located below the stage.

The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light from the illuminator onto the specimen. Microscopes with a stage condenser lens render a sharper image than those with no condenser lens.
The simple microscope was invented first by Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, the father of microscopy and microbiology. It uses 1 lens for magnification. The compound microscope, introduced by Hans and Zacharias Janssen uses 2 lenses, an objective lens and an eyepiece, to provide better magnification power than the simple microscope.
Solution to Question 2:
A painless genital ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy with the presence of spiral organisms on microscopy is suggestive of syphilis. It is caused by Treponema pallidum, demonstrated
by dark-field microscopy.
Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It uses reflected light and has a higher resolving power than the light microscope. Dark-field microscopy is the the most specific and sensitive technique to visualize Treponema pallidum when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present.
Other options:
Option B: Phase contrast microscopy improves the contrast to delineate structures within cells. A dark image is formed on a light background.
Option C: Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorescent dyes like auramine-rhodamine to appreciate Mycobacterial species and malarial parasites.
Option D: The electron microscope, invented by Ernst Ruska, helps in appreciating viral structures. It has a very high resolving power.

Solution to Question 5:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.
The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:
Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant.
Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

Solution to Question 7:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.
Fimbriae, also called pili, are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. They are primarily seen in Gram-negative bacteria. They are polymers of pilin. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili - for adhesion - and sex pili - involved in bacterial conjugation. The functions of pili are given below:
Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.
Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
Resistance to phagocytosis.
Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
Twitching motility to bacteria.
Solution to Question 8:
Pasteurization is done at 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes.
Pasteurization is the process of applying heat to milk to kill or stunt the growth of pathogenic bacteria. It was developed by Louis Pasteur. There are two methods for pasteurization:
Holder method: Milk is heated at 63°C for 30 minutes
Flash process: Milk is heated to 72°C for 15–20 seconds
Once heated appropriately, the milk is cooled quickly to 13°C or lower. All the non-sporing pathogens (mycobacteria, brucellae, salmonellae) are killed in pasteurization. In the Holder method, heat resistant Coxiella burnetti may survive.
Note: Louis Pasteur pioneered the techniques of pasteurization and sterilization. He also first advanced the germ theory of disease which states that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Furthermore, he disproved the theory of spontaneous generation and developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera. He is thus known as the father of modern microbiology.

The method of sterilization that involves exposure at 100°C for 20 minutes for 3 successive days is called tyndallization or intermittent sterilization.
Tyndallization, which utilizes steam, was used for sterilization of media containing gelatin, egg, serum, or sugar. This method may not kill spores of certain anaerobes and
thermophiles. Autoclaving has replaced this method now. Other options:
Option A: Autoclaving involves heating at 121°C for 15 minutes at a pressure of 15psi. This is the used for intruments, linen, laboratory ware.
Option C: In pasteurization, milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.
Option D: Heating an article at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days is called inspissation.

Lysol works by disrupting the cell membrane.
Lysol is a phenol compound, which is obtained by distillation of coal tar. Phenols cause cell membrane damage and inactivate membrane-bound oxidases and dehydrogenases. This causes lysis and release of cell contents. Low concentrations of phenol can precipitate proteins. They are not inactivated by organic matter and are thus useful disinfectants.

Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows antibiotic sensitivity testing which uses the lawn culture method.
Lawn or carpet culture is the method in which a uniform surface growth of bacterium is present on the medium. It is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing (disc method) and bacteriophage typing. Stab culture (option D) is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacterium, for maintenance of stock cultures. Streak culture (option A) is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. Stroke culture (option C) is used for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests. Other methods of culture include:
Liquid culture - These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.
Pour plate culture - It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.

Solution to Question 12:
The given image shows Quellung reaction (halo around the bacteria) and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it.
In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope. The anticapsular antibodies bind to the capsule and thus the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen. Capsulated organisms can be remembered with the following mnemonic:
Some - Streptococcus pneumoniae Killers - Klebsiella pneumoniae Have - Haemophilus influenzae Nice - Neisseria meningitidis
Capsules - Cryptococcus neoformans
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical vignette of fever and hemoptysis in a labourer with the sputum smear showing acid-fast bacilli is suggestive of tuberculosis. Mycobacterium tuberculosis, detected on sputum smear, is appreciated by Ziehl-Neelsen staining, which would includes carbol fuschin - acid - alcohol - methylene blue.
Acid-fast bacteria (like MTB) in a stained Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) smear appear bright red against a blue background. Steps involved in ZN staining are:
Place the sample on slide evenly spread it with rotational movement
Air-dry the slide and fix it by passing it over a flame
Apply carbol fuschin stain and heat to fix it.
Wash with water to remove excess stain
Decolourise with alcohol
Apply Methylene blue/Malachite green stain
Wash with water to remove excess stain
View under the microscope
Kinyoun modified the classical ZN staining such that heat fixing is not required. It is called the cold method. It involves increasing the concentration of phenol acid and the duration of staining. The slide is then washed with water and decolourized with acid alcohol. Counterstaining with Loeffler's methylene blue or malachite green is done for a minute and viewed under a microscope. Acid-fast bacteria in a stained smear appear bright red against a blue background.
The image attached below summarizes the steps.

Option A: It depicts the order of Gram staining, which was discovered by Hans Christian Gram in 1884.
Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet or gentian violet).
Application of dilute solution of iodine.
Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline).
Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting colour (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red).
Option B: It includes the steps for performing Albert's stain which is used for detected Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
A heavy smear of the bacterial isolate is prepared on a glass slide and allowed to dry without fixing.
Albert’s stain is applied for (3-4) minutes. Then it is washed with water and Albert’s iodine is applied for one minute.
Wash with water and let dry with blotting paper.
Examine the slide under oil immersion.
Corynebacterium diphtheriae are slender bacilli with an arrangement resembling the letters V or
L. They have metachromatic granules at the poles of bacilli which are also called polar bodies, volutin, or Babes-Ernst granules. Albert staining is useful in the demonstration of metachromatic granules. The presence of metachromatic granules helps to distinguish C.diphtheriae from diphtheroids which lack them. The images below show Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Solution to Question 14:
The aetiological agents of 1 and 2 are microaerophilic. The given case scenarios are:
A businessman with epigastric pain and positive urease test has peptic ulcer disease, caused by Helicobacter pylori. It is microaerophilic.
Diarrhea caused by Gram-negative, small, spirally curved rod-like, motile bacilli describes Campylobacter jejuni. It is microaerophilic.
Rice-water diarrhea and Gram-negative curved bacilli with 'fish-in-stream' appearance describes cholera caused by Vibrio cholerae. It is a facultative anaerobe.
Nasopharyngeal swab from a child with paroxysmal cough showing 'mercury drops' colonies describes Bordetella pertussis. It is an obligate aerobe.
Dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies on LJ medium describes Mycobacerium tuberculosis. It is an obligate aerobe.
Microaerophilic organisms grow best in low oxygen tension (2-10% oxygen).
Note: Mycobacteria, such as M. bovis, can grow at oxygen tensions ranging from atmospheric to microaerophilic conditions. However, M. tuberculosis is an obligate aerobe.
Solution to Question 15:
The given image shows MacConkey agar. Cysteine is not a constituent of MacConkey agar.
MacConkey agar is a differential or indicator medium. Lactose-fermenting organisms (Eg: E. coli) produce a pink color, and non-lactose fermenting organisms (Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.) do not change the color. Contents of MacConkey agar include peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red and
sodium taurocholate (Mnemonic- PLANT). MacConkey agar is also a selective medium i.e. the bile salts (sodium taurocholate) and dyes (neutral red) inhibit the growth of Gram-positive organisms and Gram-negative cocci.

The other images represent:

Image C- Loeffler's serum slope, which is used to isolate C. diphtheriae Image D- Chocolate agar with F. tularensis colonies
Enrichment media suppress the growth of commensal bacteria and allow for the growth of certain organisms. These media are used for samples with mixed flora e.g. stool. They are always liquid media, like alkaline peptone water. Other examples include tetrathionate broth and selenite-F broth for Salmonella sp. and Shigella sp.
Enriched medium are those media to which additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg are added. They're used to grow bacteria with specific nutritional requirements. Examples include blood agar to test the hemolytic property of bacteria, chocolate agar for isolation of H. influenzae and Loeffler's serum slope for isolation of C. diphtheriae.

Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following:
Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D)

Gram-negative halophilic bacteria- Vibrio parahaemolyticus
Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.
Solution to Question 18:
Bacterial transduction occurs by bacteriophages.
Transduction is a process of acquiring bacterial DNA from a bacteriophage (virus) that has incorporated bacterial DNA from previous host bacteria.
Other methods of exchange of genetic material are transformation and
conjugation. Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria. Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.

PCR is an automated process in which a single or a few copies of a DNA piece is amplified to generate of thousands to millions of copies of that particular DNA sequence. There are 3 basic steps are involved in PCR:
DNA extraction from microorganism
Amplification of extracted DNA - Denaturation (95°C), Primer annealing (55°C), Extension

Solution to Question 20:
The enzyme involved in RT-PCR is reverse transcriptase (RT) which has RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity.
In reverse transcription-polymerase chain reation (RT-PCR), reverse transcriptase synthesizes DNA from the RNA template. RT-PCR can be used for the demonstration of poliovirus RNA, causing paralytic poliomyelitis, in CSF. It can also be used for the detection of viruses from nasopharyngeal swabs (SARS-CoV2, H1N1).
In real-time RT-PCR, fluorescent dyes or DNA probes are used to quantify the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. So, it can be used to quantify viral loads in HIV, hepatitis B, etc., and is also called quantitative PCR (qPCR).

Solution to Question 21:
Jumping genes are also called transposons.
Transposons are genetic elements that can move between chromosomal and extra-chromosomal DNA molecules. Insertion of a transposon leads to acquisition of new characteristics by the recipient DNA. Transposons contain several genes, including those necessary for their migration from one genetic locus to another. They may contain genes for specialised functions like antibiotic resistance. However, they do not contain genes for their replication.
Jumping genes were discovered by Barbara McClintock and she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1983 for the same.
Other options:
Options A and B: The cytoplasmic carriers of genetic information are termed plasmids or episomes.
Option D: A cosmid is a type of hybrid plasmid that contains a Lambda phage cos sequence. (Cos sites + plasmid = cosmids).

Sanitization is the process through which pathogenic organisms are reduced to safe levels on inanimate objects to reduce the likelihood of cross-infections. It is a component of hand-hygiene, which is demonstrated by the image below.

Solution to Question 23:
The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization which utilises hydrogen peroxide.
In plasma sterilisation, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapours are passed. This generates plasma which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus.
Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilisation heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillius atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilus.
Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. It destroys spores and vegetative cells, but is not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilisation and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius.
Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilise biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theatres and laboratories.

Solution to Question 1:
The immunity conferred to a neonate receiving the BCG vaccine is artificial active immunity, as it involves administering a live attenuated vaccine form of Mycobacterium bovis to stimulate an adaptive immune response and develop antibodies, establishing long-term immunity.
Types of adaptive immunity:
Natural active immunity: It results from either a clinical or an inapparent infection by a microbe.
Artificial active immunity: It is the resistance induced by vaccines which are preparations o killed or attenuated microorganisms or their products.
Natural passive immunity: It is the immunity passively transferred from mother to baby. In human infants, maternal antibodies are transmitted predominantly through the placenta, while in animals such as pigs, the transfer of antibodies occurs mainly through the colostrum.
Artificial passive immunity: It is the resistance passively transferred to a recipient by the administration of antibodies. Hyperimmune sera of animal or human origin, convalescent sera, and pooled human immunoglobulin are used for this purpose.
Combined immunization: A combination of the active and passive methods of immunization is used.
Examples of the above types of immunity:
Note: Adoptive immunity is immunity in which immunologically competent lymphocytes are injected. The transfer factor is composed of these immunologically competent lymphocytes. It can passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

Giving pre-formed immunoglobulin (e.g. Tetanus immunoglobulin) directly is an example of passive immunity, which is not long-lasting.
The differentiating features between active and passive immunity:
Negative phase: It is the time period during which the level of measurable immunity is lower than it was before the antigenic stimulus. This is because the antigen combines with any pre-existing antibody and lowers its level in circulation. It is seen at the beginning of the active immune response.
Secondary type response: If an individual who has been actively immunized against an antigen experiences the same antigen subsequently, the immune response occurs more quickly and abundantly than during the first encounter.

Solution to Question 1:
B lymphocytes reside in the splenic follicles.
Lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system. They include B lymphocytes and T lymphocytes. B lymphocytes mature in the bone marrow and then migrate to secondary lymphoid organs - follicles of spleen and in follicles of lymph nodes. T lymphocytes are produced in the bone marrow but mature in the thymus. They are also present in the periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths (PALS) of spleen and paracortex of lymph node.
In a lymph node, follicles may contain a central region called germinal centre. This contains B cells that have been stimulated by an antigen.

Solution to Question 2:
Turning blue on breastfeeding with resolution on squatting describes a tet-spell or a cyanotic spell, indicating a congenital cardiac defect. Cleft palate, cardiac defects and hypocalcemia (parathyroid hypoplasia/aplasia) suggest a diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. In this disorder, a decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph nodes is noted.
DiGeorge syndrome is characterised by thymic aplasia, causing a deficiency of T cells and absent cell-mediated immunity. Thus, paracortical areas of lymph nodes and periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, where T cells reside, are reduced in size. B cells are usually not affected.

Solution to Question 4:
Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells.
Naive CD4+ T cells are activated when they come in contact with two ligands - MHC class II and a costimulary membrane protein (eg: CD28). Both of these are present in antigen-presenting cells, the most potent of which is the mature dendritic cell. Other professional antigen-presenting cells include macrophages and B lymphocytes (option C).
Other options:
Option B: Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.
Option D: NK cells do not stimulate naive T cells.

Solution to Question 5:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.
A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.
Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.
Solution to Question 6:
 TCR recognize different type of antigens without the requirement of major histocompatibility complex (MHC)
Each T cell recognizes a specific bound antigen by means of an antigen-specific T-cell receptor
(TCR). The TCR is a heterodimer and is of two types:
 TCR (95%) recognize peptide antigens that are presented by MHC molecules on the surfaces of antigen-presenting cells.
 TCR (5%) recognize peptides, lipids, and small molecules, without a requirement for display by MHC proteins. They have particular localization patterns in the mucosal tissues, which protec against microbes that try to enter through epithelia.
TCRs are non-covalently bound to six polypeptide chains or three dimers (a  pair, a  pair, and a  or  pair), forming the CD3 complex and the  dimer. The CD3 complex and  dimer convey signals received by the receptor to the interior of the cell.
Solution to Question 7:
HLA complex of genes is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (chromosome 6p21).
The human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system or complex is a gene complex encoding the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype. The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells.
The HLA system is highly polymorphic. Each individual’s HLA alleles differ from the other. It has to be checked before organ transplantation. The HLA complex consists of 3 separate clusters of genes:
Class I– A, B and C loci
Class II– DR, D› and DP loci
Class III– Complement C2 and C4 of classical pathway and properdin factor B of the alternate pathway, heat shock proteins(HSP), TNF  and .

Solution to Question 9:
Red blood cells are anucleated cells that lack MHC class I antigens.
MHC class I antigens are present on platelets and all nucleated cells, except sperm cells. They are responsible for the presentation of peptide antigen to CD8 T cells.
The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC), or the HLA complex, is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc. HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. The genes are clustered in three regions named MHC region-I, II and III.
MHC class II antigens are present only on antigen-presenting cells (macrophages, dendritic cells, B cells). They present the peptide antigen to CD4 T cells. APCs also contain MHC class I antigens.
MHC region III comprises of genes that code for complement factors like C2, C4, C3 convertase, factor B and properdin, heat shock protein, tumor necrosis factor and steroid 21-hydroxylases.
Solution to Question 10:
CD4+ is a marker of T helper and memory cells. They do not produce immunoglobulins.
CD4+ T cells are activated when an antigen-presenting cell expressing MHC-II binds to them. The activated CD4+ T cell differentiates into T helper (TH) cells and regulatory T cells. The TH cells are further differentiated into TH1, TH2 and TH17 cells. Helper T cells have the following functions:
Activation and proliferation of cytotoxic T cells
Regulation of monocyte-macrophage system
Activation of B cell to produce plasma cells
Production of interleukins
Memory cells (Tm) have both CD4+ and CD8+ markers. They provide anamestic immune response and are thus responsible for immunogenic memory.
Immunoglobulins are produced by the plasma cells.

Solution to Question 13:
Natural killer cells (NK cells) act on virus-infected cells with reduced MHC expression.
NK cells are a subtype of lymphocytes that kill damaged or infected cells. NK cells express CD16 and CD56. Their action is inhibited when MHC I is expressed on normal cells. This prevents NK Cells from killing normal cells. In the presence of a viral infection or malignancy, MHC expression of a cell is reduced. Thus, NK cells get activated and kill virus-infected/tumor cells. NK cells also secrete cytokines (IFN-) which activate macrophages (option B) for destruction of ingested microbes.
Other options:

Option D: Helper T cells act when cells expressing MHC II (antigen-presenting cells) present exogenous antigens.
Solution to Question 14:
A child with colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting with eosinophilia likely has a parasitic infection with Ascaris lumbricoides (egg shown in the image). Parasitic infections trigger the release of IL-5.
In a parasitic infection, Th2 cells are stimulated and they produce IL-4 and IL-5. IL-4 stimulates the differentiation of B-cells into IgE-secreting plasma cells, while IL-5 stimulates the maturation and release of eosinophils from the bone marrow. The secreted IgE coats the parasite. The activated eosinophils bind to the IgE-coated parasite and kill them through the release of major basic protein.

It activates macrophages, increases neutrophil function, enhances both MHC class 1 and class II expression and has anti-proliferative

Solution to Question 4:
This child who developed tingling in the mouth, and swelling of the lips and face after eating shelf life is an example of an IgE mediated type of hypersensitivity reaction.
Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and affects the whole body. It is characterized by a sudden release of histamines and other chemicals from the immune system in response to an allergen, such as certain foods, medications, insect stings, or latex. The onset of symptoms can occur within minutes to a few hours after exposure to the allergen.The primary mediators are histamine and serotonin. The secondary mediators are prostaglandins and leukotrienes.
Clinically, anaphylaxis can present with a combination of symptoms that typically include:
Respiratory Symptoms: Patients often experience wheezing and respiratory distress due to bronchoconstriction. Other signs may include shortness of breath, coughing, and a feeling o tightness in the chest.
Skin Symptoms: Urticaria (hives) and angioedema (swelling of the skin and mucous membranes) are common. These skin reactions usually develop rapidly, often within minutes to two hours o exposure to the allergen.
Cardiovascular Symptoms: Hypotension (low blood pressure) is a key indicator of anaphylaxis. Patients may also experience tachycardia (increased heart rate) and, in severe cases, shock.
Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps can occur, particularly if the anaphylaxis is triggered by food allergens.
Neurological Symptoms: Dizziness, lightheadedness, or loss of consciousness can occur due to the sudden drop in blood pressure and reduced oxygen supply to the brain.

Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.
Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs.
Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Solution to Question 1:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.
It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects.
Disorders of phagocytosis:
Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
Chediak–Higashi syndrome
Chronic granulomatous disease
Tuftsin deficiency
Cyclic neutropenia Other options:
Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.
Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections.
Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.
Solution to Question 2:
linked or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is primarily a disease of humoral immunity. Cell-mediated immunity is not affected.
It is an inherited immunodeficiency disease caused by mutations in the gene coding for Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). B cells do not differentiate and mature. They are arrested in the pre-B cell stage.
There are extremely low IgG levels (below 100 mg/dL) and an absence of other immunoglobulin classes. The tonsils and lymph nodes are usually atrophic. Lymph node biopsy reveals depletion of cells of B cell-dependent areas (follicles). Babies born with this disorder have virtually no peripheral B cells (<1%) and suffer from recurrent bacterial infections.
Solution to Question 3:
The Nitroblue Tetrazolium Test (NBT) is used as a screening test for chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) by assessing the reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in phagocytes.
This principle relies on the color change of nitroblue tetrazolium, which transforms from colorless/yellow to deep blue when it encounters ROS. A higher nitroblue test score indicates that the cell is more efficient in producing ROS.
In chronic granulomatous disease, there is an NADPH oxidase defect. Hence, the phagocyte cannot produce reactive oxygen species or radicals required for bacterial killing, which results in recurrent infections. Here, the leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium during phagocytosis. Hence, a negative test (NBT remains colourless to yellow) is seen in CGD.

Solution to Question 4:
The history here is highly suggestive of Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS), a condition characterized by decreased IgM levels.
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity.
The clinical features of WAS are a triad of recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia (with small platelets). Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. IgA and IgE levels are normal or elevated.
Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS.

Solution to Question 5:
A child with multiple abscesses (as shown in the image above) with a history of atopy and recurrent respiratory infections suggests immunodeficiency, and the most probable diagnosis is Hyper IgE syndrome.
The hyper-IgE syndromes are rare primary immunodeficiency syndromes characterized by recurrent severe staphylococcal abscesses of the skin, lungs, and other sites, eczema, eosinophilia, and marked elevation of serum IgE levels. They occur in 2 forms:
Autosomal dominant - involves mutations in the gene encoding STAT-3 (also known as Job syndrome)
Autosomal recessive - involves mutations in DOCK8.
In Job syndrome, mutation of the STAT3 gene leads to IgE overproduction without modulation. Loss of modulation is due to the absence of anti-inflammatory cytokines IL-6, IL-10, and
IFN-gamma. Lack of IL-6 leads to deficiency of CD4 + Th17 cells, making them susceptible to various infections.
It usually presents as a triad of atopic dermatitis, recurrent skin staphylococcal infections, and recurrent pulmonary infections that occur early in childhood. The eczematoid rash affects the scalp and face, gets superinfected with Staphylococcus aureus and forms cold abscesses. Candida infections are common. Recurrent staphylococcal pneumonia with pneumatocoeles is also
commonly seen. Other non-immunological features are:
Dysmorphic facial features that appear in early adolescence and are absent in the autosomal recessive form
Craniosynostosis
Arnold-Chiari type 1
Hyperextensible joints
Scoliosis
Pathological fractures
Retention of primary teeth
Vascular complications
Ocular complications
Diagnosis is based on measurements of serum IgE levels >2000U/mL where IgA, IgG and IgM concentrations are generally normal, in adjunct with the clinical features seen in Job syndrome. It is associated with peripheral blood eosinophilia.
The treatment primarily focuses on preventing infections through the use of antimicrobials, including antibiotics and antifungals, along with immunoglobulin replacement therapy.
Solution to Question 6:
Louis–Bar syndrome or ataxia-telangiectasia is a combined immunodeficiency disorder. Ataxia-telangiectasia is a syndrome complex that comprises neurologic, immunologic,
endocrinologic, and cutaneous disorders. The gene involved in this condition is the mutation in the ATM gene mapped to the long arm of chromosome 11(11q22-23). The mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive. There is defective DNA repair and increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation.
Clinical features:
Progressive cerebellar ataxia
Oculocutaneous telangiectasias
Chronic sinopulmonary disease
High incidence of malignancy - adenocarcinomas and lymphoreticular tumors (lymphoma,
leukemia, and Hodgkin's disease)
Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency
Ovarian dysgenesis and chromosomal abnormalities
Hypoplastic thymus
Ataxia and chorioathetoid movements start in infancy.
The onset of telangiectasia is around 3 to 6 years and involves the face, conjunctiva and other parts of the body. By 12 years of age, affected children are usually confined to wheelchairs due to progressive ataxia.
Death occurs due to sinopulmonary infection in early life or due to malignancy in the second or third decade. They lack IgA and IgE. Cell-mediated immunity is also defective.

Solution to Question 7:
The given history of recurrent bacterial infections and fungal pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii (as shown in the image above), along with elevated IgM and low IgG levels, are suggestive of hyper-IgM syndrome, an inherited deficiency in the CD40 ligand or CD40.
Hyper-IgM syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder that is inherited as:
X-linked form (most common): CD40 ligand (CD40L) defect on T-helper cells, preventing B-cell activation, class switching and memory cells formation.
Autosomal recessive form: Affect CD40 on B-cells or enzymes like activation-induced cytidine eaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme expressed in B cells.
The B-cell response to T-independent antigen is unaffected. CD40–CD40L interactions are also required for IL-12 secretion. So, defects in this pathway result in increased susceptibility to intracellular pathogens.
In normal immune response, B-cells expressing CD40 on their surface interact with CD40L on
T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM with extremely low levels of IgG and no IgA or IgE.
Clinical features include recurrent pyogenic infections caused by low levels of opsonizing IgG antibodies. Patients are highly susceptible to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.
The illustration below depicts the defects in components of T-cell & B-cell interactions that give rise to primary immunodeficiency.

Other options:
Option A: Defective cytokine signalling in T-cell precursors is seen in X-linked Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID). It is caused by a mutation in the common -chain (c) subunit of cytokine receptors. This defect disrupts Interleukins (IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15 and IL-21) signalling, leading to low T-cell and NK-cell numbers. Although B-cell numbers are normal, these are non-functional due to the absence of T-cell help, resulting in impaired antibody synthesis.
Option B: Mutation in the STAT3 gene is seen in an autosomal dominant form of Hyper IgE syndrome (also known as Job syndrome), characterized by recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent pulmonary infections often with pneumatoceles and atopic dermatitis. Here, serum IgE levels are markedly elevated (due to IgE overproduction without modulation), and IgA, IgG and IgM concentrations are generally normal.
Option D: A defect in NADPH oxidative pathway is seen in chronic granulomatous disease, leading to failure of the oxidative burst in phagocytes, predisposing individuals to
catalase-positive microbial infections.
Solution to Question 8:
This 5-year-old boy presenting with a 2-year history of thick, white-coated tongue and dystrophic nail changes, as shown in the above image, suggests chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, for which transfer factor therapy and amphotericin B have been reported to be the effective treatments.
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis (CMC) is characterized by deficient cell-mediated immunity to candida, usually due to defects in IL-17. Mutations affecting the IL-17 signalling pathway lead to
impaired IL-17 production and defective TH17 function, compromising mucosal and skin defence mechanisms and increasing susceptibility to fungal infections.
Patients develop persistent fungal infections of the skin, nails, oral cavity, and genitals, primarily caused by Candida species. Despite chronic mucocutaneous involvement, these patients typically do not develop invasive candidiasis. A key feature of CMC is the absence of delayed hypersensitivity to candida antigens. However, circulating antibodies to them are present in high titres. They do not show increased susceptibility to other infections but may develop endocrinopathies, autoimmune disorders, and vascular abnormalities.
Transfer factor therapy and Amphotericin B have been reported to be effective for the treatment of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.
Solution to Question 9:
This history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord with recurrent pneumonia and peripheral leucocytosis is highly suggestive of leucocyte adhesion defect (LAD). In this defect, there is reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X.
LAD is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting leukocyte function. Neutrophils have reduced adhesion, mobility, and phagocytic ability. There are three main types of LAD:
LAD 1- Defective 2 integrin common chain (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion.
LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X (fucosylated protein), leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling and tethering.
LAD 3- Defect in regulatory protein (kindlin 3, also known as Fermt 3) involved in activating the ligand affinity for 2 integrins, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion (milder than type 1).
LAD is characterised by recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, reduced inflammatory responses despite elevated blood neutrophilia, and delayed wound healing and delayed umbilical cord loss. in patients with LAD type 3, there may be bleeding as 2 integrin on platelets is
non-functional.
Typical signs of inflammation may be absent, pus does not form with few neutrophils on biopsy of infected tissues along with massive hyperleukocytosis (>30,000/L) in the blood. Early allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is used in the treatment of severe LAD.
Solution to Question 10:
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities.
Severe combined immunodeficiency disorders are associated with severe deficiency of both humoral and CMI. They are inherited in both X-linked and autosomal recessive modes. There are different forms of this disorder:
Reticular dysgenesis is the most serious form of combined immunodeficiency. Here the defect is at the level of the multipotent hemopoietic stem cell.
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is associated with enzyme deficiency. The condition is associated with chondrocyte abnormalities which can be discerned radiologically.
Swiss-type agammaglobulinemia is associated with lymphocytopenia and severe defect in CMI. The basic defect is at the level of the lymphoid stem cell.
Solution to Question 11:
The seminiferous tubules are an immunologically privileged site.
Immunologically privileged sites can tolerate the introduction of antigens without eliciting an immune response. This allows a higher likelihood of graft survival, even without perfect HLA matching. As a result, an allograft can be placed in these sites without endangering a rejection reaction.
The unique immune tolerance in these regions is primarily due to the lack of effective lymphatic drainage, which prevents antigen presentation to the immune system, and the presence of
blood-tissue barriers that restrict immune cell infiltration. Low vascularity contributes to immune privilege by minimising antigen exposure and immune cell recruitment.
Examples of immune-privileged sites are the anterior chamber of the eye, cornea, testes, and brain.
Note: Although part of the brain, the blood-brain barrier is absent at the area postrema, therefore it is not an immune-privileged site.

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A -hemolytic streptococcus).
Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive inflammatory infection of the fascia, with secondary necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues. It has also been referred to as Meleney ulcer, acute dermal gangrene, hospital gangrene, suppurative fasciitis, and synergistic necrotizing cellulitis. The source of the infection is either the skin, with organisms introduced into the tissue through trauma, or the bowel flora, with organisms released during abdominal surgery.
The onset of symptoms is usually quite acute and is marked by severe pain at the site of involvement, malaise, fever, chills, and a toxic appearance. The affected limb is edematous with the overlying skin turning dusky with mottled erythema and the development of hemorrhagic bullae.

Solution to Question 1:
An infected wound culture showing Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters which are coagulase-positive suggest that the cultured organism is Staphylococcus aureus.
Staphylococci are Gram-positive cocci that are catalase-positive. They grow in clusters because the cells divide successively in three perpendicular planes, with the daughter cells remaining attached to one another following each successive division. Among the 45 different species of Staphylococcus, Staphylococcus aureus is the only one which is coagulase positive.
Other options:
Option A: Streptococci are catalase negative. They are Gram-positive cocci arranged in chains. Options C & D: S. epidermidis and S. saprophyticus are both coagulase negative.

Staphylococcus: Clusters
Streptococcus: Chains
Pneumococcus: Pairs/lanceolate shaped
Micrococcus: Tetrads
Solution to Question 2:
Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters that produce golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar is suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C.
Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus. On nutrient agar, its colonies are large (2-4 mm in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque and easily emulsifiable. The colonies appear golden yellow due to the presence of staphyloxanthin (carotenoid). Pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C and in aerobic conditions. It is enhanced when 1% glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium.
On a nutrient agar slope, there is confluent growth of Staphylococcus, which appears as a characteristic oil-paint appearance.
Solution to Question 3:
Protein A forms the basis of the co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus.
Protein A bearing staphylococci are coated with IgG antiserum. Protein A binds to the Fc terminal of IgG, leaving the Fab terminal free to combine with its specific antigen. The corresponding antigen is then added to this mixture which causes agglutination of the bacteria. This is known as the co-agglutination reaction. It is used for streptococcal, gonococcal or hemophilus typing.

Solution to Question 4:
-hemolysin exhibits a hot-cold phenomenon.
-hemolysin is a sphingomyelinase that is hemolytic only for sheep cells but not human cells. It initiates hemolysis at 370C but the hemolysis is evident only after chilling. This is called the hot-cold phenomenon.
Solution to Question 5:
-toxin and Panton-Valentine-toxin (leucocidin) of Staphylococcus aureus are called synergohymenotropic toxins.
Synergohymenotropic (synergo - working together, hymenotropic - form pores) toxins are a family of bicomponent toxins that act through the synergistic activity of 2 non-associated secretory proteins - class F and class S proteins. Gamma hemolysin has two components necessary for its hemolytic action. It is encoded by three genes HlgA and HlgC (belonging to class S) and HlgB (belonging to class F), resulting in 2 pairs of class S and F components - HlgA and HlgB, or HlgC and HlgB.
Panton-Valentine Leucocidin is composed of two components- S and F - encoded by two contiguous and cotranscribed genes, lukS-PV and lukF-PV. It is associated with the majority of community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA).
Solution to Question 6:
Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated.
Septicemia occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream. This causes an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis - fever, hypotension, alkalosis.
Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections include food poisoning caused by enterotoxin, toxic shock syndrome caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin.

Solution to Question 8:
Penicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is determined by plasmids that are most commonly transferred by transduction.
Penicillin resistance in Staphylococci most commonly occurs due to bacterial production of beta-lactamase, which inactivates penicillins by splitting their beta-lactam ring. These enzymes are inducible and are plasmid-mediated. They confer resistance to penicillin G, ampicillin, piperacillin etc.
The genetic transfer of antibiotic resistance can occur in the following ways:
Transformation: After death or cell lysis, some bacteria release their DNA into the environment. Other bacteria, generally of the same species, can come into contact with these free DNA fragments, take them up and incorporate them into their DNA by recombination.
Transduction: This method involves the transfer of DNA, episome or plasmid from one bacterium to another with the use of a bacteriophage.
Conjugation: This mechanism requires the presence of a special plasmid called the F plasmid that codes for the sex pilus. It is the most common method of transfer of antibiotic resistance in most other bacteria.
Note: Change in penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) and production of -lactamases are modes of penicillin resistance seen in S. aureus but the question asks for methods of transfer of drug resistance.
Solution to Question 9:
Contact based isolation is employed for patients who are infected with MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus).
The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:
Contact-based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).
Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Among the given options, washing hands before and after treating the patients is the most effective way to curb the spread of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections.
In addition to this, personnel with active S. aureus lesions and carriers should be excluded from areas having patients at highest risk for severe staphylococcal infections like newborn nurseries, intensive care units, operating rooms, and cancer chemotherapy wards. In such individuals, the application of topical antiseptics such as mupirocin to nasal or perineal carriage sites may diminish the shedding of MRSA.
Solution to Question 11:
The most common cause of botryomycosis is Staphylococcus aureus.
Botryomycosis is a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous disease that usually involves the skin and rarely viscera. It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus but can also be caused by Pseudomonas, Escherichia coli, Proteus, and Streptococci. Patients present with chronic, suppurative, granulomatous skin lesions like nodules, abscesses and sinuses.
Actinomycetoma, eumycetoma and botryomycosis are difficult to distinguish clinically but are readily distinguished with microbiologic testing or biopsy. Granules of botryomycosis consist of loose masses of cocci. Organisms can also be seen in wound discharge or histologic specimens.
Solution to Question 12:
Vomiting 2 hours after the consumption of food is likely food poisoning by Staphylococcus aureus.
Staphylococcus aureus can grow in carbohydrate and protein food sources, producing enterotoxins. There are 15 types, all of which are superantigens. They are preformed toxins that are relatively heat stable. They stimulate the vagus nerve, vomiting centre of the brain and intestinal peristaltic activity. Type A enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning.
The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Ingestion of such contaminated food causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

Fever, sore throat and difficulty in swallowing with the presence of a dirty white pseudomembrane on the posterior pharynx is strongly suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They are described as club-shaped gram positive bacilli.
Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram-positive, non-sporing, non-capsulated and non-motile bacilli. They possess polymetaphosphate granules that serve as storage granules and are called metachromatic granules. These give the bacilli a beaded or club-shaped appearance on microscopic examination.

Solution to Question 2:

Solution to Question 3:
Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is not a selective medium as other organisms can also grow on this medium.
The selective media for Corynebacterium diphtheria are potassium tellurite agar, Tinsdale medium and McLeod's medium (tellurite blood agar). Tellurite inhibits the growth of other bacteria. C. diphtheria reduces the tellurite to metallic tellurium, giving its colonies a grey black colour. On
On Loeffler's serum slope, colonies appear as small white opaque discs that may acquire a yellow ting. The advantages for growing C. diphtheriae on Loeffler's serum slope are rapid growth in 6-8 hrs and that its the best medium for metachromatic granules production. The disadvantage of using this medium is that on incubation beyond 6-8 hrs, it supports the growth of commensals as well.
Solution to Question 4:

Macleod classified diphtheria bacilli based on colony morphology on tellurite blood agar into the following three types:
Gravis: They form daisy head colonies and are variably hemolytic. They ferment glycogen and starch.
Intermedius: They form frog’s egg colonies and are non-hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.
Mitis: They form poached egg colonies and are hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.

The toxin produced by the bacteria - diphtheria toxin - inhibits polypeptide chain elongation and protein synthesis by inactivating the elongation factor-2 (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation. It has two fragments - fragment B helps in binding of the toxin to host cells and fragment A inactivates EF-2.

Solution to Question 6:
Lysogenic or phage conversion is seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
The toxigenicity of diphtheria bacillus depends on the presence of the corynephages (tox+). When the bacillus is cured of the phage, its toxigenic capacity is lost.
A bacteriophage is a virus that parasitises bacteria. It can carry host DNA and transfer it to another bacterium. In lysogenic conversion, the viral DNA is integrated with the bacterial DNA and thus can code for new characteristics, like toxin production. The conversion of non-toxigenic bacterial strains to toxigenic by infecting them with bacteriophages is known as lysogenic conversion.

Solution to Question 7:
Toxin production of Corynebacterium diphtheriae depends on the concentration of iron in the medium, presence of tox phage, and its biotype. Concentration of zinc in the medium has no effect on this process.
An increase in iron concentration (option A) upregulates the DT (diphtheria toxin) repressor gene, thereby decreasing the toxin production. The optimum level of iron in the medium for toxin production is 0.14 g/millilitre, while a concentration of 0.5 g/millilitre inhibits the formation of toxins.
The gene for diphtheria toxin is coded by bacteriophage (corynebacteriophage tox+) and thus the presence of phages (option B) is integral to toxin production. Toxin production also depends on the biotype (option C) - gravis, intermedius, mitis and belfanti - of the bacilli. All four biotypes are toxigenic.
Diphtheria toxin is also produced by Corynebacterium ulcerans and Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis.
Solution to Question 8:
Elek's test is used to test the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
Elek's gel precipitation test is an in vitro immunoprecipitation (immunodiffusion) test used to determine whether or not a strain of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is toxigenic. In this test, a rectangular strip of filter paper impregnated with diphtheria antitoxin is placed on the surface of a 20% normal horse serum agar. Narrow streaks of the C. diphtheriae strains are made at right angles to the filter paper strip with positive and negative controls. If the strain produces toxins, the toxin will diffuse in the agar and produce a line of precipitation (arrowhead) where it meets the antitoxin at optimum concentration.

Diphtheroids ferment both sucrose and glucose, whereas Corynebacterium diphtheriae ferments only glucose.

They are corynebacteria resembling C. diphtheriae which occur as normal commensals in the throat, skin, conjunctiva and other areas.

Erysipeloid usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, in people who handle animals, fish or animal products. Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast filamentous organisms with hyphae-like branching on microscopy. They are aerobic, gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease-positive. Solution to Question 7: The first sign of generalized tetanus is increased tone of the masseter muscle, which results in trismus or lock-jaw. Tetanus: Route of entry of organism- injury, unhygienic surgery, abortion/delivery, otitis media The incubation period is 6-10 days. First clinical sign- increased masseter tone (trismus/lock-jaw) followed by descending tetanus Deep tendon reflex is exaggerated. In neonates, difficulty in feeding is the usual presentation. Diagnosis is always clinical, microscopy is unreliable. Treatment includes cleaning the entry wound first in order to remove anaerobic foci of infection and prevent further toxin production. Metronidazole is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early in an attempt to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin. Spasms are controlled by heavy sedation with benzodiazepines. Symptomatic treatment is given for respiratory and cardiovascular derangements. Solution to Question 8: Tetanus toxin has similar mechanisms of action as strychnine but acts pre-synaptically. This leads to increased release of acetylcholine, thereby leading to the development of spastic paralysis. The image below depicts the mechanism of action of tetanus toxin. The clinical syndrome of botulism consists of bilateral cranial-nerve palsies that may progress to respiratory compromise, a bilateral descending flaccid paralysis of voluntary muscles, and even death. Cranial nerve deficits may manifest as some of the following: diplopia dysarthria dysphonia ptosis ophthalmoplegia facial paralysis and impaired gag reflex The absence of cranial nerve palsies makes botulism highly unlikely, as does a lack of cranial nerve deficits at the onset of illness. Pupillary reflexes may be depressed and fixed or dilated pupils are sometimes noted. The cornerstones of treatment for botulism are meticulous intensive care and administration of botulinum antitoxin. This patient with chronic cough and hemoptysis with a concurrent history of significant weight loss and night sweats most likely has tuberculosis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
McLeod's medium is not used to culture M. tuberculosis. It is a selective medium for Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis include:

Liquid- Middlebrook’s media are used for the preparation of antigens and vaccines and i sensitivity testing. Other examples of liquid mycobacterial culture media include Dubos' medium, Sula's medium and Sauton's medium.

Solution to Question 7:
Xpert MTB/RIF detects tuberculosis (TB) and rifampicin resistance simultaneously within 2 hours. It is a fully automated, real-time nucleic acid amplification technology, with high specificity and sensitivity.
The WHO recommends its use worldwide as the initial diagnostic test in adults and children who are presumed to have multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) or HIV-associated TB. Xpert MTB/RIF should also be the first test applied to the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of patients in whom tubercular meningitis is suspected as well as a replacement test (over conventional microscopy, culture, and histopathology) for gastric lavage, pleural and other biopsies, and fine-needle aspiration specimens.

The disc diffusion technique is not suitable for testing Mycobacterium tuberculosis because the organism grows so slowly that the drug has time to diffuse throughout the medium, and sharp zones of inhibition are not seen.

Solution to Question 9:
TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV(who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).
Interferon-gamma release assays include:
QuantiFERON-TB Gold
T-SPOT.TB
QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IFN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only
TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CDù+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.
T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-.
The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample. (Option A and B)
Solution to Question 10:
Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in the mycobacterial cell wall, released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis.
Urine LAM is a useful tool in diagnosing tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV and low CD4+ T cell count.
Most diagnostic tests for tuberculosis rely on sputum samples, which are difficult to obtain and have low sensitivity in immunocompromised patients, patients with disseminated TB, and children, delaying treatment initiation. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) is the only WHO-endorsed TB biomarker that can be detected in urine, an easily collected sample.

Solution to Question 13:
QuantiFERON-TB gold is not a type of tuberculin skin test. It is a type of interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs), a whole-blood test that can aid in diagnosing Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
There are 3 described methods for tuberculin skin testing (TST):
Mantoux test, also known as the Pirquet test (preferred method)

In contrast, IGRAs that have been approved by the FDA are:
QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT)

IGRA is not used in India due to a higher probability of a false positive due to universal BCG vaccination. It can also lead to a diagnosis of active TB in a patient with latent TB and may lead to overtreatment. This test is banned in India after the WHO advised against it in low and
middle-income countries.

Solution to Question 1:
Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a pigment-producing species of mycobacteria.
M. scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen which produces yellow or orange colored pigments, even in the dark. It belongs to group II of Runyon's classification. It can cause scrofula or cervical adenitis in children.
M.ulcerans, M.avium intracellulare complex (MAC), and M. xenopi belong to group III-non photochromogens as they do not form pigment even on exposure to light.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is a commonly used, egg-based, selective media for mycobacteria. It contains:
Egg- Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism

Glycerol- Source of carbon, favors growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis. LJ medium without glycerol, which contains pyruvate, is used for culture of M. bovis.

Solution to Question 4:
Mycobacterium ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer.
M. ulcerans produces a toxin called mycolactone which leads to formation of Buruli ulcer. This is a chronic, debilitating, necrotizing disease of the skin and soft tissue which is characterized by the formation of ulcers that progressively enlarge over time if left untreated. The ulcers heal with disfiguring scars.
The image below shows a Buruli ulcer.

Option A: Hunner's ulcers are seen in a subset of patients with interstitial cystitis. These are areas of inflammation on the bladder wall.
The image below shows a cystoscopic image of a Hunner's ulcer.

Option B: Meleney's ulcer or post-operative synergistic bacterial gangrene occurs in immuno-compromised individuals following abdominal surgery. It is caused by a synergistic interaction between microaerophilic nonhemolytic Streptococcus and hemolytic aerobic Staphylococcus aureus.
Option D: Marjolin ulcer is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds.
The image below shows a Marjolin's ulcer in a burn scar.

Solution to Question 5:
The image shows a fish tank granuloma that is caused by M. marinum.
The typical clinical presentation is as a single, small violet papule or nodule confined to one extremity, developing 2-3 weeks after trauma. The nodule may break down to form an indolent ulcer. M. marinarum is a natural pathogen of fish and amphibians, which spreads to humans who come in contact with contaminated swimming pools or fish tanks.
Other non-tuberculous mycobacteria causing disease in humans include:
M. kansasii: Disease resembles pulmonary TB
M. scrofulaceum: Cervical lymphadenitis
M. avium complex: Pulmonary, disseminated TB, especially in AIDS patients
M. fortuitum: Nail salon furunculosis
M. paratuberculosis (aka Johne’s bacillus) causes Johne’s disease in cattle. It is associated with Crohn’s disease in humans.
Solution to Question 6:
The image depicts leonine facies in a patient suffering from leprosy or Hansen's disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It is cultivated in nine-banded armadillos and footpads of mice.
M. leprae is a Gram-positive, weakly acid fast bacillus. Thus, 5% sulphuric acid (option A) is used for decolourisation to demonstrate M.leprae's acid-fastness. On microscopy, the bacilli appear bound together in masses called globi, within which they are arranged in a 'cigar bundle' appearance.
For leprosy diagnosis, specimens are collected from the nasal mucosa, skin lesions and earlobes. Nasal smears are collected from the internal septum of the nose. Skin smears are collected from the edges of the lesions (option B) rather than from the centre. Slit skin smears are taken as well. The skin is pinched up tight to minimise bleeding and a cut is made with a scalpel, deep enough to get into the infiltrated layers. This is done over the buttocks, forehead, chin, cheek, and ears (at least 5-6 different areas) (option C).
Solution to Question 7:
The generation time of lepra bacilli is 12-13 days.
Generation time, also known as doubling time, is the time it takes for the bacterial population to double. It can also be measured as the time between two cell divisions under optimum conditions. The generation time of different bacilli are given below:
Lepra bacilli- 12-13 days average (may vary from 8-42 days)
Tubercle bacilli- 15-20 hours
Coliform bacilli- 20 minutes

Solution to Question 9:
Statements 2, 4, and 5 regarding lepra reactions are correct.
Type 2 lepra reactions are unrelated to drug therapy, whereas type 1 reactions may occur within a year of starting treatment.
New lesions typically appear in type 2 lepra reactions. They are tender and erythematous subcutaneous and dermal nodules. Existing lesions show no changes.
Solution to Question 10:
The lepromin test has value as a prognostic test for leprosy.
The lepromin, or Mitsuda test, is a method to measure cellular immunity in leprosy. It is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin and the induration reaction is measured 3–4 weeks after.
It is used to classify leprosy. A negative lepromin test is seen in lepromatous and borderline leprosy. It is negative in children <6 months of age, it may be positive at the end of 1st year. BCG vaccine is capable of converting a negative lepromin test to a positive.
Solution to Question 11:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection.
Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just
under the skin.
The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive.
Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.
Solution to Question 12:
Mycobacterium indicus pranii is the basis for the development of a leprosy vaccine.
The leprosy vaccine species was originally called Mycobacterium W (M.w) but was later renamed Mycobacterium indicus pranii. The vaccine is administered via intradermal route. The dose is 0.1 ml. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms.
Booster doses will be given to maintain the immunity level. These are given only in one arm.

Solution to Question 4:
This patient with watery diarrhea most likely has traveller’s diarrhea caused by Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC).
Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism that causes diarrhea in travelers. It produces the following toxins:
LT (heat-labile toxin) - acts by cAMP
ST (heat-stable toxin) - two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by  cGMP in the intestine.
ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known. Other options:
Option A: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli.
Option B: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.
Option D: Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test.
Solution to Question 5:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).
E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.
EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.
Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

Shiga toxin or verotoxin is an exotoxin produced by Shigella species. It consists of two subunits A and B. The B subunit binds to globotriaosylceramide receptors on the target cell, and then, the A subunit gets internalized. The A subunit leads to inhibition of 60S ribosome, leading to shut down of protein synthesis. Its site of action is in the endothelial cells of small blood vessels of GIT.

Enteric fever is caused by S. typhi or S. paratyphi. The minimum amount of S. typhi required to cause enteric fever is 103 to 106 organisms.
Enteric fever spreads through the feco-oral route. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop abdominal distension, diarrhea, splenomegaly and characteristic rose spots on the abdomen due to vasculitis.

The given image shows Rose spots. The combination of this with fever, splenomegaly, presence of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine and intestinal perforation is suggestive of enteric fever.
The term enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C.
Enteric fever presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever is accompanied by relative bradycardia which is known as the Faget sign. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on
examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week.
Since bile is a good culture medium for the bacilli, they multiply abundantly in the gallbladder and are discharged continuously into the intestine. In the intestine, it causes inflammation and

Solution to Question 8:
The tube agglutination test which is widely used for the diagnosis of enteric fever is the Widal test. The O antibodies detected via this test disappear within a few weeks of disease resolution and so are indicative of recent infection.
Widal test is a serological test for the measurement of O and H antigens of Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi present in the patient's serum. Four antigens are used- O antigens of S. typhi (TO), H antigens of S. typhi (TH), H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH) and H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH).
Paratyphoid O antigens cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen due to the sharing of factor 12. It is not used in the test and thus, O antibody cannot differentiate between Salmonella types.
H agglutinin titer > 160 and O agglutinin titer > 80 is considered significant. However,
a 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is more significant compared to a single high titer because of the possibility of an anamnestic reaction - a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue) in persons who had a prior enteric fever. After one week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction.
Solution to Question 9:
Widal results showing titers for O antibody >80 and H antibody for S.typhi to be >160 is suggestive of enteric fever. Faget's sign is seen in enteric fever.
Enteric fever, caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C, presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever rises one day and falls the subsequent morning. It continues to form peaks and troughs. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week. Faget's sign is the unusual pairing of fever with bradycardia (relative bradycardia) instead of tachycardia. It is also observed in yellow fever, brucellosis, and tularemia. Intestinal perforation (option A) is a complication of enteric fever caused by Salmonella typhi. It occurs in the 3rd week following infection.
Widal test is a serological test used for the diagnosis of enteric fever during the 2nd week. It measures the levels of H and O antigens in the patient's serum.
Bone marrow culture is the gold standard (option D) for diagnosis of enteric fever. Blood culture is most commonly performed to confirm the diagnosis, however, bone marrow is more sensitive.

Solution to Question 10:
Bone marrow culture is preferred at this stage.
Bone marrow culture is the most sensitive test (>80% sensitivity) for diagnosis of enteric fever. It remains positive for upto 5 days after starting antibiotics, unlike blood culture. Hence, it is preferred in the patient above who has been on antibiotics for 2 days.
Blood culture has a sensitivity of about 60% for diagnosis of enteric fever. Its sensitivity drops with duration of illness, and is thus useful onlyduring the 1st week of enteric fever. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics. Stool culture has a sensitivity of 30% and only yields positive results from the 2nd or 3rd week onwards. Urine culture has low sensitivity and may be positive only after the 2nd week.
Note: The sensitivity of diagnostic methods for enteric fever is duodenal content culture > bone marrow culture > blood culture. However, duodenal content culture is rarely done in clinical practice.
Solution to Question 11:
Vi capsule polysaccharide antigen is a heat-labile antigen used in the Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (ViCPS) for typhoid.
Vi antigen is found in Salmonella typhi, S. paratyphi C and S. dublin. It is a capsular antigen and is a polysaccharide. It acts as a virulence factor by inhibiting phagocytosis and resisting complement activation and bacterial lysis. It envelopes the O antigen, and thus, many S. typhi strains fail to agglutinate with O antiserum. However, it can be destroyed by heat. It is alcohol stable. This antigen is poorly immunogenic.
The Vi capsular polysaccharide vaccine (Vi CPS) contains purified Vi polysaccharide. It is given as a single dose of 0.5ml intramuscularly to children over 2 years of age. It is recommended for travellers to areas endemic for Salmonella infections.
Solution to Question 12:
The oral typhoid vaccine is given on days 1, 3, 5, and 7.
Typhoral or Ty21a is a live attenuated oral typhoid vaccine. It is given in 4 doses given on days 1, 3, 5, and 7. No antibiotics should be given during this period. lt is indicated only in individuals over 6 years of age. Protective immunity starts after 7 days of the last dose and lasts for 4 years. Ty21a can also be administered to HIV-positive, asymptomatic individuals as long as their CD4 count is above 200/mm3. It is contraindicated in immunocompromised patients.
Solution to Question 13:
Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever.
Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.

Solution to Question 14:
The given case scenario is suggestive of non-typhoidal salmonellosis (NTS). The most common organism isolated in NTS from stool culture is Salmonella typhimurium.
Nontyphoidal salmonellosis refers to illnesses caused by all serotypes of Salmonella except for Salmonella typhi, Salmonella paratyphi A, B, and C. Transmission of nontyphoidal salmonellosis occurs usually through the consumption of food or water contaminated with animal feces.
Transmission may also occur through food products, especially eggs, poultry, undercooked ground meat, and hence multiple animals act as reservoirs for non-typhoidal salmonella.
Gastroenteritis is the most common clinical presentation of NTS. The illness usually lasts 4–7 days, and most people recover without treatment. Culturing organisms continues to be the mainstay of clinical diagnostic testing for nontyphoidal salmonella infection. Approximately 90% of isolates are obtained from routine stool culture until 4-5 weeks after infection.
