Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:
The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to th GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit,
on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes. This leads to watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate.
The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and lectrolyte depletion thus caused.

Solution to Question 1:
Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis with a history of repeated lung infections since childhood and evelated sweat chloride concentration suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).
In cystic fibrosis, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, lungs are often colonized in infancy and early childhood with Staphylococcus aureus and Haemophilus influenzae. In adulthood, they are replaced by P. aeruginosa. This results in chronic inflammation, which leads to airway modelling and bronchiectasis.
Note: Burkholderia cepacia complex is an opportunistic environmental pathogen. It causes fata respiratory distress and septicemia in CF patients. This is termed as 'cepacia syndrome'.
Solution to Question 2:
Scombroid fish poisoning is associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
It follows the consumption of both scombroid (mackerel-like) fish and nonscombroid fish that have not been refrigerated properly. The musculature of these dark- or red-fleshed fish undergoes decomposition by Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Proteus species, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. There is consequent decarboxylation of the amino acid L-histidine to form histamine.
A second compound is thought to play a causative role in this intoxication because large doses of oral histamine do not reproduce the affliction. The toxin or toxins involved are heat stable and are not destroyed by cooking or freezing.
Symptoms develop within 15–90 min of ingestion. Most cases are mild, with tingling of lips and mouth, mild abdominal discomfort, and nausea. The more severe and commonly described presentation includes flushing, conjunctival hyperemia, pruritus, urticaria, and
angioedema. Without treatment, the symptoms generally resolve within 8–12 h.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the only member of the Pseudomonas species that produces pyocyanin which is a bluish-green pigment. Other species of Pseudomonas also produce pigments but they cannot produce pyocyanin. Some of the other pigments produced by Pseudomonas species including P. aeruginosa are pyoverdin/flourescein (greenish-yellow pigment), pyorubin (red pigment) and pyomelanin (brown pigment).
Solution to Question 4:
The action of exotoxin A of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is similar to that of the diphtheria toxin.
Both exotoxin A and diphtheria toxin cause ADP ribosylation of EF-2 and inhibit protein synthesis. Exotoxin A is a single-chain polypeptide with A and B fragments. The B fragment binds the toxin while the A fragment inactivates EF-2 in the presence of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD). This leads to the inhibition of polypeptide chain elongation and thus, protein
synthesis.

Solution to Question 9:
Post-tussive vomiting and bouts of cough in an unimmunized child points to a diagnosis of pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis. It secretes pertussis toxin (PT), which acts by ADP ribosylation and disrupts signal transduction of many cell types. This promotes lymphocytosis.
The pertussis toxin disrupts protein synthesis and causes necrosis of parts of the epithelium, leading to pseudomembrane formation. Pertussis toxin also promotes sensitization to histamine and enhances insulin secretion but these effects have not been demonstrable in patients. They are only seen in experimental animals.
Adenylate cyclase toxin (ACT)- It acts by catalysing the production of cAMP by various types of cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.
Heat labile toxin (HLT)- It is a cytoplasmic protein present in all bordetellae. It is dermonecrotic and lethal in mice. Its pathogenic role is not known.
Tracheal cytotoxin (TCT)- It is low molecular weight peptidoglycan which induces ciliary damage in hamster trachea.
Solution to Question 10:
Pertussis toxin (PT) can be toxoided.
PT is one of the toxins produced by Bordetella pertussis. It is expressed on the surface of the bacillus and secreted into the surrounding medium. It has an A-B structure, the A portion being the enzymatically active moiety and B, the binding component. PT is similar to cholera toxin in its structure and function. PT has ADP-ribosylating activity and acts on inhibitory Gi  subunit of
G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR), whereas cholera toxin acts on stimulatory Gs  subunit of
GPCR.
Pertussis toxoid is the major component of the acellular pertussis vaccine. A toxoid is a toxin that has lost its toxicity but retains its antigenicity.
Solution to Question 11:
Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis. Filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA) is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium.
Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins: Pertussis toxin (PT), lipid factor and FHA. FHA is a surface protein and is readily shed. Along with fimbrae, it helps in the adhesion of B. pertussis to the cilia of the respiratory epithelium and to erythrocytes. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci. They then assists their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'.
Solution to Question 12:
The incubation period of pertussis in humans is 7-14 days.
Pertussis is caused by Bordetella pertussis. After the incubation period, the disease takes a protracted course comprising three stages:
Catarrhal: It lasts 1-2 weeks and is characterized by coryza, lacrimation, mild cough, low-grade fever, and malaise.
Paroxysmal: It lasts 2-4 weeks with the cough becoming more frequent and spasmodic. The cough comes in repetitive bursts of 5–10 in number, often within a single expiration.
Post-tussive vomiting is frequent. The episode may be terminated by an audible whoop, which occurs upon rapid inspiration against a closed glottis at the end of a paroxysm.
Convalescent: It lasts 1–3 months and is characterized by gradual resolution of coughing episodes.
Whooping cough is also known as '100-day cough'. For 6–12 months following the illness, intercurrent viral infections may be associated with a recrudescence of paroxysmal cough.
Solution to Question 13:
The given case scenario of whooping cough, post-tussive vomiting, and abdominal pain, along with positive history of exposure in an unimmunised child is suggestive of pertussis.
Erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such as azithromycin or clarithromycin is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition.
Antibiotic therapy in pertussis is used to eradicate the bacteria from the nasopharynx. The treatment is beneficial if it is started within 10 days of the disease. Macrolides are the drugs of
choice. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Cotrimoxazole) is recommended as an alternative for individuals allergic to macrolides. Macrolides may also be used in the chemoprophylaxis of pertussis. Post-exposure prophylaxis is given to household close contacts, and high-risk contacts (infants, immunocompromised, pregnancy).
Solution to Question 14:
Whooping cough is caused by Bordotella pertussis. The most effective method for collecting a specimen for the culture of this organism is the per-nasal or nasopharyngeal swab method.
Respiratory specimens may be collected for the culture (gold standard) of Bordetella pertussis by three different methods:
Per-nasal swab: A Dacron or rayon tipped swab on a flexible nichrome wire is passed along the floor of the nasal cavity and material is collected from the pharyngeal wall. This specimen is
the most effective and best suited for diagnostic procedures.
Cough plate method: A culture plate is held about 10 to 15 cms in front of the patient's mouth during a bout of cough.
Post-nasal (peroral) method: Secretions from the posterior pharyngeal wall are collected with a cotton swab on a bent wire passed through the mouth.
Other diagnostic tests for pertussis include direct fluorescent aantibody test and PCR on nasopharyngeal specimens. Enzyme immunoassays of antibodies after exposure to B. pertussis can also be used for patients between 2-4 weeks of illness.
Solution to Question 15:
Tdap vaccine is the tetanus, diphtheria and acellular pertussis vaccine. The component of the acellular pertussis vaccine is inactivated pertussis toxin (PT) and it may contain one or more bacterial components such as pertactin, filamentous hemagglutinin, and fimbrial protein.
Pertussis vaccine is usually administered in combination with the toxoids of diphtheria and tetanus (DTaP). Five doses of pertussis vaccine are recommended - at 2, 4, 6 and 15–18 months of age followed by a booster dose at 4–6 years of age.
Tdap is now also recommended for pregnant women in between 27 weeks and 36 weeks of gestation by the ACOG. This is because infants between the age of 0-2 months are vulnerable to pertussis as they do not begin their vaccine schedule before 6 weeks of age. Thus to protect these infants, placental transfer of maternal pertussis antibodies has proven to be the most effective approach. Children under 4 years who are contacts of patients should receive a booster even if they had been previously immunized. Non-immunized contacts should receive full series of vaccination and also chemoprophylaxis with erythromycin for 10 days after contact with the patient has ceased.

The given clinical vignette and 'thumb sign' on the X-ray are suggestive of acute epiglottitis caused by Hemophilus influenzae.
It is an acute inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing.
The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the Thumb sign.
In some countries, widespread vaccination against Hib has drastically decreased acute epiglottitis cases in children by over 90%. However, the incidence in adults has remained largely unchanged since the Hib vaccine was introduced. Despite vaccination efforts, many pediatric cases of epiglottitis today are still caused by Hib due to either lack of vaccination or vaccine ineffectiveness. In adults and increasingly in children, other bacterial pathogens, particularly group A Streptococcus, have been linked to cases of epiglottitis.
Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone.

H.infiuenzae is a Gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporing bacillus, exhibiting considerable
pleomorphism. In sputum, it usually occurs as clusters of coccobacillary forms.
The bacillus has fastidious growth requirements. The accessory growth factors, named X and V, present in the blood are essential for growth. Catalase and

Cultures may be preserved for about a month on chocolate agar slopes. Chocolate agar is made by heating blood agar to 80-90°C for 15-20 minutes. This causes the release of V factor from within the erythrocytes.

Milk ring test (MRT) is positive for Brucella. It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy farms.
A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min. Brucella suis is primarily an intracellular pathogen affecting reticuloendothelial system. This accounts for its refractoriness to chemotherapy.
Solution to Question 3:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur.
Other options
Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.
Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.
Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue. Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.

The given case scenario of remittent fever with anemia with a positive Rose Bengal card test is suggestive of brucellosis. Castaneda method for blood culture is used to isolate Brucella sp.
In the Castaneda method, blood is inoculated into a bottle of trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in a biphasic blood culture bottle (with liquid and solid media in the same bottle). This method minimizes materials and manipulation, thus reducing the chances of contamination and risk of infection to laboratory workers.
Blood cultures are positive in only 30–50% of cases even when repeated samples are
tested. B.melitensis and B.suis are isolated more readily than B.abortus. The below image shows Castaneda's bottle.

Milk ring test

The usual alternative regimen (and the current World Health Organization recommendation) is rifampin plus doxycycline. However, this is associated with a higher relapse rate, possibly because rifampicin increases clearance of doxycycline and reduces serum doxycycline levels.
In children, cotrimoxazole along with rifampicin or gentamycin may be used for the treatment of brucellosis.
Note: B. melitensis is endemic to the Middle East.

Rat-bite fever (RBF) is characterized by fever, rash, and arthralgia which usually occurs days or weeks after a bite.
The two types of rat-bite fever are:
Streptobacillary RBF develops 2–10 days after a rat bite, associated with sudden onset of fever, headache, and myalgia followed by petechial rash and arthritis. It is also called Haverhill fever or Erythema arthrititicum epidemicum.
Spirillary RBF is similar to streptobacillary type but it is also associated with regional lymphadenopathy. It is also called Sodoku.
Diagnosis is based on demonstration of causative organisms in peripheral blood films. Serology can also be used for diagnosis.
RBF is treated with intravenous Penicillin G. Alternative drugs include ampicillin, cefuroxime, and cefotaxime.

The given case scenario of sudden-onset fever with painful lymphadenopathy and a history of similar complaints in the community is suggestive of a diagnosis of plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The septicemic form of the disease may be acquired directly if the bacteria enter the bloodstream via infected blood transfusions.
Wild rodents and their infected fleas are the primary reservoirs of Yersinia pestis. Infection is transmitted to humans by the bite of infected fleas.
Human plague occurs in 3 clinical forms (in increasing order of severity): bubonic plague< pneumonic plague< septicemic plague
Bubonic plague- It is the most common variety of the disease. It is named after the buboes meaning swollen lymph nodes, which typically develop within a week after an infected flea bite. Other clinical features include sudden onset of fever and chills, headache, and fatigue.
Pneumonic plague- Bubonic plague can advance and spread to the lungs. It is the most virulent form of plague. Any person with pneumonic plague may transmit the disease via droplets to other humans. The symptoms include dyspnoea, chest pain, cough, fever, and hemoptysis.
Septicemic plague- When the bacteria enter the bloodstream directly and multiply there, it is known as septicemic plague. When left untreated, both bubonic and pneumonic plague can lead to septicemic plague.
Solution to Question 10:
The drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of plague is doxycycline. It is given for 7 days to all close contacts of a patient having pneumonic plague.
Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin are the other first-line drugs used for antimicrobial prophylaxis.
The drug of choice for the treatment of plague is streptomycin. Streptomycin is nephrotoxic and ototoxic and should, therefore be cautiously used. Doxycycline or ciprofloxacin (and other fluoroquinolones) are considered as alternative drugs for the treatment of plague.

Two distinct clinical patterns of legionellosis have been identified:
Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea rapidly progressing to pneumonia if left untreated. Patients can also develop a hyponatremia. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Atypical pneumonia is also caused by:
Chlamydia pneumonia
Chlamydia psittaci
Mycoplasma pneumonia
Coxiella burnetii
Viruses such as influenza virus, adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus
Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza-like illness with fever, chills, myalgia, and headache.
Other options:
Option A: Chlamydia pneumonia causes pharyngitis, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It has also been associated with adult onset asthma. Outbreaks have been reported in closed communities. Real-time PCR is used for its diagnosis.
Option C: Haemophilus influenzae typically causes pneumonia in infants. While the primary infections occur due to capsulated strains, bronchopneumonia may occur as a secondary infection due to non-capsulated strains. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.
Option D: Klebsiella pneumonia causes fatal pneumonia, which occurs in middle -aged or older persons with risk factors such as alcoholism, chronic bronchopulmonary disease or diabetes mellitus. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.

Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g., polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3–6 days to appear.

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol–bromothymol blue) agar
Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

No animal reservoirs exist. No evidence of human-to-human transmission has been found and no carrier state is established.

Patients present with a painless papule or pustule at the site of the scratch and lymph node enlargement and can be suppurative. The disease is usually self resolving. Solution to Question 2:
This patient has a high-grade fever and is a student, so he presumably spends a lot of time in crowded areas. The above image shows a purpuric rash. This patient's features are seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis, which are gram-negative diplococci.
The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From the nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.
Solution to Question 3:
Infection with Neisseria meningitidis is most commonly asymptomatic colonization in the nasopharynx of healthy individuals. Hence, a nasopharyngeal swab is used in the detection of carriers. In some patients, local inflammation ensues with rhinitis and pharyngitis.
Ceftriaxone as a single-dose IV/IM injection is highly (97%) effective in the eradication of carrier state and can be used at all ages and also in pregnancy. Ciprofloxacin is also highly effective and can be given orally, but it is not recommended in pregnancy and below 18 years of age.
Solution to Question 4:
Polysaccharide vaccines of Neisseria meningitidis do not offer protection against group B meningococci. This is because the group B capsule is made up of sialic acid residue which is also expressed on the surface of neural cells in the fetus. So, the B polysaccharide is perceived as 'self' and is poorly immunogenic.
To overcome this issue and provide protection against group B meningococci, a new vaccine was developed based on the surface protein i.e., non-capsular antigen of serogroup B meningococci. This is the multicomponent meningococcal vaccine - 4CMenB.
Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccines developed based on capsular antigen can be classified as:
Plain polysaccharide vaccines:
Bivalent (A and C),
Trivalent (A, C and W-135)
Tetravalent (A, C, Y, and W-135)
Conjugated polysaccharide vaccines:
Monovalent (A or C)
Quadrivalent (A, C, Y, and W-135) MenQuadfi vaccine

Solution to Question 10:
Gonorrhea in males most commonly manifests as acute urethritis.
In males, the disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis. Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation. The infection may also spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).
In females, the initial infection involves the cervix, uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) which may also occur
following Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

Though Waterhouse-Freiderichsen syndrome is most often associated with meningococcal septicemia, it may complicate sepsis caused by other organisms like certain streptococcal species also. May fall into a coma

Solution to Question 1:
Transovarial transmission is a feature of Orientia tsutsugamushi which causes scrub typhus.
Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. Orientia tsutsugamushi is maintained by transovarial transmission in trombiculid mites. It is also seen in Rickettsia rickettsii, Rickettsia conorii, and Rickettsia akari.
The image below shows a trombiculid mite.

Trench fever (option D) is caused by Bartonella quintana.
Solution to Question 2:
Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. A cell wall is present in rickettsial organisms.
Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative pleomorphic coccobacilli. They are unable to grow in cell-free media and are thus cultured in yolk sacs of embryonated eggs. They are
non-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They reproduce by binary fission and are transmitted by arthropods like ticks and lice (except Coxiella burnetii and Bartonella henselae).
The rickettsiae are localized in endothelial cells of small blood vessels (except Ehrlichia and Anaplasma) in humans. They cause endothelial cell enlargement and degeneration, predisposing
to thrombus formation. Tetracyclines, macrolides, and fluoroquinolones are effective against this group but, beta-lactams are ineffective.
Solution to Question 3:
The vector for endemic murine typhus is the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.
Endemic murine typhus is cuased by Rickettsia typhi (option B) while epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The zoonotic reservoir for R. typhi is the rat. Humans are infected when flea feces contaminate pruritic bite lesions. Transmission can also occur via inhalation of aerosols of dried feces of rickettsemic rat flea. No man-to-man transmission occurs. Patients present with fever, chills, vomiting and a maculopapular rash that is more prominent on the trunk. Diagnosis is by serology and treatment is with doxycycline.
When male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with blood from a case of endemic typhus, they develop fever and a characteristic scrotal inflammation. The scrotum becomes enlarged and the testes cannot be pushed into the abdomen. This is known as the Neil-Mooser reaction. It is positive with Rickettsia typhi (option D) and negative with Rickettsia prowazekii.
The image below shows the rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis.

Solution to Question 5:
Epidemic typhus rash spares the palms and soles.
Epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, is transmitted by the louse Pediculus humanus corporis. There is no transovarial transmission of R. prowazekii. The disease spreads through infected louse feces deposited when the louse feeds on the human host. It is commonly seen in poor unhygienic or cold conditions.
Epidemic typhus starts with fever and chills. A characteristic rash appears on the fourth or fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such latent infection may, at times, be reactivated leading to recrudescent typhus (Brill-Zinsser disease).
Transovarial transmission refers to passing on the disease-causing bacteria from parent arthropod to offspring arthropod. It occurs with Orientia tsutsugamushi, Rickettsia rickettsii, R. conorii and
R. akari.
Note: Rash on palms and soles is typically described in Rocky Mountain spotted fever, secondary syphilis and hand, foot, and mouth disease

Solution to Question 6:
The drug of choice for scrub typhus is doxycycline.
To treat scrub typhus, oral doxycycline 100 mg is given twice daily for 7–15 days. In the case of pregnant women, oral azithromycin 500 mg for 3 days may be used as doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy.
Scrub typhus is a rickettsial infection caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is a trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. Patients develop a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. It can be associated with fever, headache, myalgia, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia.
Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction used for diagnosis, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of Proteus strains OX19, OX2, and OXK. OXK alone is agglutinated in scrub typhus.

As chlamydia is a bacteria, it possesses both DNA and RNA. Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. They are filterable like viruses. Chlamydiae occur in two forms, the elementary body and the reticulate body. The extracellular, infective form is called the elementary body. These are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the inclusion body which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell wall of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism. Solution to Question 2:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless ulcer with indurated base points towards the diagnosis of syphilis.
Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.
It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods.
Fontana's method is used on smear
Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:
Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule
that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.
Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.
Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the
classic iritis or uveitis.
Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero.
Neurosyphilis: The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.
Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.
Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.
Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
(CDC):
Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS,
TPHA, EIA/CIA)
Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin.
Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic presentation of the severe disease called Weil’s syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative bradycardia can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone.
The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis.

Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test.
Transmission occurs through cuts or breaks in the skin and mucous membranes (conjunctival and oral mucosa). Several outbreaks have been reported that resulted from exposure to floodwaters contaminated by urine from infected animals. The organism enters the bloodstream and lodges in the parenchymatous organs (liver and kidneys) leading to hemorrhage and necrosis of the tissue
causing dysfunction of the organs.

Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are:
Acute leptospiremic phase- the organism can be cultured from blood.
Resolving immune phase- the organism can be cultured from urine. The stages may not be clinically distinguishable.

Blood transfusion carries the highest risk per 10000 exposures of getting HIV from an infected person. However, it is not the most common mode of transmission.
Solution to Question 6:
The risk of HIV acquisition associated with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is relatively higher than that seen in penile-vaginal intercourse. This is because the rectal mucosal membrane is thin and fragile and anal intercourse is associated with microtrauma (rectal tears).
The differences in transmission rates between men and women are because the vagina and cervix are exposed to semen for a longer duration, increasing the risk of transmission. However, the penis and urethral orifice are exposed relatively briefly to infected vaginal fluid, lowering the risk.

In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner.
The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.
The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

Solution to Question 9:
The given patient is in the latent period of HIV infection. During the latent phase of HIV infection, the CD4+ T cell count declines steadily and not rapidly.
All patients infected with HIV pass through a phase of clinical latency during which they are asymptomatic. This can last for years. During the latent phase, patients show positive HIV antibody tests and they are infectious. There will be varying degrees of viral multiplication.
Throughout the course of untreated infection and even during the stage of clinical latency, HIV is actively replicating or is sequestered in lymphoid tissues.

Solution to Question 10:
Antibodies against gp41 will be detected first by ELISA or Western blot.
Antibodies to HIV usually appear within 3–6 weeks of primary infection. The appearance of HIV-binding antibodies occurs prior to the appearance of neutralizing antibodies. The only viral proteins that elicit neutralizing antibodies are the envelope proteins gp120 and gp41.
The order of appearance of antibodies is as follows:
Antibody to envelope gp41 > Antibodies to gag protein (p24 and p55) > Antibodies to envelope gp120 > Antibodies to gag protein p17 > Antibodies to pol gene products (p31 and p66).
Note: The earliest antigen to appear in the blood following HIV infection is p24.
Solution to Question 11:
ELISA is most commonly used as a screening test for HIV.
Screening tests possess high sensitivity but are not highly specific. ELISA is a simple, relatively inexpensive screening test.
The most commonly used confirmatory test is Western blot. Western blot demonstrating antibodies to products of all three of the major genes of HIV (gag, pol, and env) is conclusive evidence of infection with HIV. It is considered positive if it shows antibodies against at least two of the following gene products: p24, gp41, gp120/160.

Stages of measles:
The natural history of measles has 3 stages as follows:
Prodromal stage - It begins 10 days after infection and lasts until day 14. It consists of cough, coryza, redness of eyes, lacrimation, photophobia, vomiting, and diarrhea. Koplik's spots appear in this stage.
Eruptive stage - A dusky, red maculopapular rash appears. It starts behind the ears spreads downwards to the trunk and lower extremities. Post-measles stage - Weakness and weight loss may persist. The infection may become chronic and cause secondary infections such as cancrum oris, candidiasis etc.

Rabies is a vaccine-preventable, zoonotic, viral disease. Once clinical symptoms appear, rabies is virtually 100% fatal.
Spread of rabies:
Centripetal spread -
The virus enters the peripheral neurons, it moves via retrograde fast axonal transport towards the spinal cord or brainstem a.k.a the central nervous system (CNS) at a speed of up to 250 mm/day.
Once within CNS, it spreads quickly to other regions in the CNS through fast axonal transport. It infects neurons primarily, but may rarely infect astrocytes.
Centrifugal spread - After CNS infection is established, it spreads along the sensory and autonomic nerves to:
Salivary glands
Adrenal glands
Skin
Rabies virus replicates in acinar cells of the salivary glands and is secreted in the saliva of rabid animals that serve as vectors.

Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complains of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.

A swelling with multiple discharging sinuses with brown granules that is unresponsive to the antibiotics is suggestive of eumycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis.
Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It can be divided into three types- eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.
Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible. It results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules.
Laboratory Diagnosis:
options: Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.

Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi. Treatment: The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole. Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C). Examples of dimorphic fungi include: Blastomyces dermatitidis Coccidioides immitis Paracoccidioides brasiliensis Talaromyces marneffei Sporothrix schenckii Histoplasma capsulatum Coccidioides posadasii Solution to Question 16: The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition include Cave's disease and Ohio disease. The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes. Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages. On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidia are seen. It is treated using azole antifungals. Solution to Question 17: The given clinical history and the characteristic pilot's wheel appearance on culture(image) is suggestive of paracoccidioidomycosis caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It is also called Lutz mycosis/ South American blastomycosis. Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. On culture, yeast form is seen at 37° C and the mycelial form at 25° C. Microscopy of tissue sample reveals thick walled, round, yeast cells with numerous buds attached to each other circumferentially giving the classic mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance. Most infections are asymptomatic and few individuals with acute disease present with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and skin lesions. It is most common in North America and so is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis. The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in the soil. Blastomycosis can present in three forms: Pulmonary disease: Presents with cough, sputum production, chest pain, and fever Hilar lymphadenopathy may be present Focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation may occur. Resembles TB and Histoplasmosis Cutaneous disease: Involvement of face and exposed parts of the skin Skin lesion: ulcerated verrucous granulomas with an advancing border and central scarring. Three serotypes fall under Cryptococcus neoformans - A(var. grubii), D(var. neoformans), and AD(a hybrid of serotypes A and D). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, the isolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished.
The serotypes B and C are now considered a different species - Cryptococcus gattii.
Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolation
of Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. C. neoformans and C. gattii produces brown
colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin. Melanin is produced by laccase using caffeic acid as the substrate.

Solution to Question 1:
Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting a human is an example of an aberrant parasite. It is defined as a parasite that infects a host where they cannot develop further.
Parasites can be classified as:
Ectoparasites - inhabit only the body surface of the host without penetrating the tissue. The term infestation is often used for parasitization. e.g., lice, ticks, and mites.
Endoparasite - lives within the body of the host and causes infection. Endoparasites are further classified as follows:
Obligate parasites - cannot exist without a host. e.g., Toxoplasma gondii and Plasmodium.
Facultative parasites - exist as either parasitic or free-living forms. e.g., Naegleria fowleri.
Accidental parasites - infects an unusual host. e.g., Echinococcus granulosus infects man
Aberrant/Wandering parasites - infects a host where they cannot develop further. e.g., Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) infecting humans.
Solution to Question 2:
A host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development is referred to as the paratenic host.
For example, in the lifecycle of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), humans are the definitive host. The first intermediate host is cyclops and the second is small freshwater fish. If the small freshwater fish with the plerocercoid larva get eaten by a larger fish, the larva survives in the larger fish. This makes the larger fish a paratenic host.
Host is an organism that harbors the parasite and provides nourishment and shelter to it. It is relatively larger than the parasite.
Types of hosts:
Definitive host - harbors stages of sexual reproduction of the parasite.
Intermediate host - harbors stages of asexual multiplication of the parasite.
Paratenic host - harbors only the larval stage of the parasite which remains viable without further development.
Reservoir host - harbors the parasite and acts as an important source of infection to other susceptible hosts, especially in endemic areas.
Accidental host - harbors a parasite that is not usually found in the host.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malaria relapse and it is caused by Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale species.
In case of P.vivax and P.ovale, two kinds of sporozoites are seen. Some multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts while others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites (resting forms). These dormant forms may get activated and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing true clinical relapse. It usually occurs after 6 to 12 months of complete cure from the disease.
In case of P.falciparum and P.malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.
In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

Solution to Question 1:
The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.
Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir.
The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer.
The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces. Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.
The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.
Note: The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar,

T. cruzi is the causative organism of Chagas disease or South American trypanosomiasis. They are intracellular parasites.
It passes its life cycle in two hosts- the definitive host is the man and the intermediate host
(vector) is reduviid bug or triatomine bugs.
Metacyclic trypomastigotes are the infective forms to the man that are found in feces of reduviid bugs. Transmission occurs when mucus membranes, conjunctiva, or wound on the surface of the skin are contaminated by feces of the bug.
Inside the definitive host, the trypomastigotes differentiate into intracellular amastigotes. The amastigotes multiply by binary fission and differentiate into trypomastigotes, which are then released into the bloodstream. These are the infective stage for triatomine bug. No multiplication occurs in this stage.
Inside the triatomine bug, the trypomastigotes are transformed into epimastigotes and then into metacyclic trypomastigotes in the hindgut which are excreted in feces.
Note: Amastigote forms resemble the Leishmania spp. and hence they are frequently known as Leishmanial forms. They are found in muscular tissue, nervous tissue, and reticuloendothelial system.

Solution to Question 9:
Sabin-Feldman dye test is used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis.
It is based on the principle that the presence of anti-toxoplasma antibodies in the patient's serum inhibits the staining of trophozoites by alkaline methylene blue dye.
Toxoplasma trophozoites and complement are added to the patient's serum which is then incubated for an hour at 37°C. After incubation, methylene blue dye is added.
If anti-toxoplasma antibodies are present in the serum, these are activated by complement and the parasite membrane is lysed. Thus, the trophozoites are not stained (positive result).
If there are no antibodies, trophozoites will take up the stain and appear blue under the microscope. This is considered to be a negative result.
The dilution of the test serum at which 50% of the tachyzoites are not stained is reported as the antibody titer of the test serum. The test is highly sensitive and specific.
It cannot differentiate between recent or past infections as it detects only IgG antibodies.
Solution to Question 10:
Human toxoplasmosis is a zoonosis. It is transmitted by cats. Toxoplasma gondii has two types of life cycles:
Enteric cycle
Exoenteric cycle
The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats. Exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.
Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within the mucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat. The tachyzoites and tissue cyst represent stages in asexual multiplication, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction.
All three forms, tachyzoites, tissue cyst, and oocyst occur in the definitive host. Only the asexual forms, tachyzoites, and tissue cysts are present in the intermediate host.
Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by the lymphatic system and blood, while the bradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst. The dormant bradyzoites inside the cyst may be reactivated on immune suppression causing renewed infection in the host.

options: parvum. The infective form is the oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, which can be acquired through drinking or during recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection or be implicated in person-to-person transmission. Because of their small size (4-5micron), they is difficult to see using routine staining. Hence acid-fast/Kinyoun's stain is used. Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from the cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea. Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been FDA approved for use in cryptosporidium infection. Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulosae.
Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection. The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:
Epilepsy
Increased intracranial tension
Hydrocephalus
Psychiatric disturbances
Meningoencephalitis
Transient paresis
Behavioral disorders
Aphasia
Visual disturbances.
The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:
Scolex within a cyst
Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
Nodular calcifications
Focal enhancing lesions
Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.
Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.
Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.
Solution to Question 4:
Development of the given symptoms following the consumption of measly pork is suggestive of intestinal taeniasis caused by Taenia solium (pork tapeworm). The eggs of Taenia solium do not float in the saturated salt solution.
The eggs of T. solium are infective to man and pigs. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to man.
The adult worm of Taenia solium is usually 2-3 meters long and the scolex has dagger-shaped hooks.
Man is the definitive host. The intermediate host is usually pig, but occasionally it can be man. The below image shows the life cycle of T. solium.

The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canids which are its definitive hosts.
The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.
Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).
Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.
Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver.
E. multilocularis leads to formation of a multilocular hydatid cyst, most commonly affecting the liver. It presents as multiple small cysts in the liver.
Note: Echinococcus granulosus causes a hollow fluid-filled unilocular cyst in the liver.
The CT below shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.
It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.

In PAIR the steps involved are:

Solution to Question 8:

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:
Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.
The clinical features of hydatid disease of lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis and chest pain. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole.

The 3 hosts of Diphyllobothrium latum are:

The given clinical scenario with cutaneous hyperpigmentation and features of subacute combined degeneration are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This can be caused by Diphyllobothrium latum.
The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to vitamin B12 deficiency. This can also lead to megaloblastic anemia (Bothriocephalus anemia).

Bilateral hypertonia

Absent deep tendon reflexes.
It is treated with parenteral vitamin B12 supplementation.

Chronic schistosomiasis presents as painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria. Fibrosis may cause obstructive uropathies like hydronephrosis and hydroureter. Solution to Question 14:
The given life cycle belongs to Fasciola hepatica.
Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.
Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.
The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.
Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence of adult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice can occur months or years later.
Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.
Solution to Question 15:
The given life cycle belongs to Clonorchis sinensis. It causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver fluke infection).
The hosts for Clonorchis sinensis are:
Definitive host- humans
First intermediate host- snai
Second intermediate host- fish
Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae). In the duodenum, metacercaria will undergo excystation and migrate to bile ducts to develop into adult worms. The eggs containing miracidia are excreted in human feces which are then ingested by snails. Miracidium hatches out in the midgut of the snail. Inside the snail, sporocyst develops into 1st and 2nd generation redia and then to cercariae. The cercariae now penetrate the fish and develop into metacercaria (infective form).
Chronic clonorchiasis is strongly associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Solution to Question 1:
Strongyloides stercoralis is an ovoviviparous parasite. Nematodes are classified as follows:
Oviparous - lay eggs:
Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichuria
Segmented eggs: Ancylostoma duodenale, Necator americanus
Eggs containing larva: Enterobius vermicularis
Viviparous - produce larvae. e.g., Trichinella spiralis, Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi
Ovoviviparous – lay eggs containing fully formed larvae that hatch immediately. e.g., Strongyloides stercoralis
Solution to Question 2:
The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.
The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.
The larvae molt twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.
The rhabditiform larva can be seen on microscopic examination of stool.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy showing the rhabditiform larva of S. stercoralis are suggestive of strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be ivermectin.
Strongyloidiasis is caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario of perianal itching and the scotch tape microscopy showing the eggs are suggestive of infestation with pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis).
The eggs of pinworm are plano-convex in shape, colorless, non-bile stained, and float in the saturated salt solution. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.
Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and the scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.
The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod, at one end of which a piece of transparent cellophane is attached with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. It is returned to the test tube and sent to the laboratory. The cellophane piece is detached, spread over a glass side, and examined microscopically.
The image given below shows the NIH swab.

In scotch tape method, the tape is firmly pressed against the anal margin, covering all sides. The tape is transferred to a glass slide with sticky side down. Then a drop of toluene is added for clearing and examined under the microscope.

The below image shows the life cycle of Enterobius vermicularis.

Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).
The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:
Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
They float in the saturated salt solution.
It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.
They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are
unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.
In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.
In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhoea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

The given clinical scenario and muscle biopsy showing larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It is caused by Trichinella spiralis.
Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever and myalgia.
These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.
Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy.
Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are:
T. solium
T. cruzi (amastigote)

Solution to Question 1:
Eijkman test is also known as differential coliform test.
Drinking water should be free of any pathogenic microorganisms. The presence of coliform bacteria in the water may indicate faecal pollution, while the detection of E.coli confirms it.
The presumptive coliform test is done by the multiple tube technique. Following this, the Eijkman test is done to confirm the presence of E. coli. They can grow at 44°C (faecal thermotolerant bacilli), ferment lactose and cause indole and gas production.
Option A: Presumptive coliform count detects the probable number of coliform bacilli in water. It can be positive due to the presence of organisms other than E.coli also.
Option C: Colony counts provide an estimate of the general bacterial purity of water.
Option D: Methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacterial contamination of milk.
Solution to Question 2:
Recent fecal contamination of water is suggested by the presence of enterococcus (fecal streptococci).
Clostridium perfringens may be present for a long duration. If it is present in water, it suggests that contamination is not recent.
If Escherichia coli is detected, it is definitive proof of fecal contamination. However, it is non-specific for suggesting the duration of the contamination.
Solution to Question 3:
Pasteurization is not used for the bacteriological examination of milk.
Pasteurization is the process of applying heat, to milk, for a specified period for the purpose of killing pathogenic bacteria. There are two methods: holder method and flash method.
Option A: Methylene blue reduction test depends on the reduction of methylene blue by bacteria in milk when incubated at 37 °C in complete darkness.
Option B: Resazurin test is similar to methylene blue reduction test, but the dye resazurin on reduction passes through a series of colour changes from blue to pink to colourless. The shade of colour after incubation with milk for a particular period of time depends on the degree of contamination.
Option C: Phosphatase test is used to check whether milk has been pasteurised. Positive test after pasteurisation of milk shows contamination after pasteurisation.
Solution to Question 4:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology. The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:
Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

Solution to Question 5:
Aminopterin is a folate antagonist present in the HAT medium that inhibits the de novo pathway of nucleotide synthesis. Since myeloma cells cannot use the salvage pathway for nucleotide synthesis due to the lack of HGPRTase enzyme, they cannot survive in the HAT medium.
Hybridoma technology is a method for producing large numbers of identical antibodies
(monoclonal antibodies).
Hybridomas are somatic cell hybrids produced by fusing the antibody-forming spleen cells with myeloma cells. The resultant hybrid thus has both the antibody-producing ability of the B-cell and the ability to multiply indefinitely of the myeloma.

Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma
cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

Solution to Question 6:
Epsilometer (E-test) is both a diffusion and a dilution method of testing antibiotic sensitivity.
It is a quantitative technique for determining the antimicrobial susceptibility (AST) and minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) in µg/mL of gram-negative and gram-positive aerobic bacteria.

The antibiotic sensitivity tests are classified as follows:
Diffusion methods: Kirby–Bauer method, Stokes method
Dilution methods: Tube dilution method, Agar dilution method
Diffusion and dilution method: E–test (Epsilometer)
Solution to Question 7:
The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.
To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).
Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:
Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer)
The image below shows Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method.

Solution to Question 8:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.
MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism.
Methods to determine MIC include:
Tube dilution method
Agar dilution method
E-test method
Solution to Question 9:
Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing.
Types of PCR:
Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained.
Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity.
Solution to Question 10:
The hemagglutination test is not based on the principle of antibody marking.
When antibodies bind to antigens on the surface of red blood cells, the resultant clumping reaction is referred to as hemagglutination. It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.
The image below shows hemagglutination.

In ELISA, radioimmunoassay and immunofluorescence, the antigens or antibodies are labeled or marked with enzymes, fluorescent dyes, etc.
Note: If no hemagglutination occurs it means the patient’s serum has anti-haemagglutinin antibodies that bind to hemagglutinin and prevent the clumping reaction. This hemagglutination inhibition reaction is a method of detection of viruses and antiviral-antibodies and is used to make a diagnosis of influenza.
Solution to Question 11:
Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of
UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity.
The screening tests for UTI are as follows:
Wet mount examination- It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
Leukocyte esterase test- It is a rapid and cheaper method and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
Nitrate reduction test (Griess test)- Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli gives a positive result.
Catalase test- E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result. Quantitative Culture:

Solution to Question 12:
CLED (Cysteine lactose electrolyte-deficient) medium is preferred over MacConkey agar for the culture of organisms involved in urinary tract infections because it is less inhibitory and promotes the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except  hemolytic streptococcus) and candida.
It is used as an alternative to the combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar, for the processing of urine specimens.
CLED medium is not similar to blood agar in the fact that it can prevent swarming of proteus. It is similar to MacConkey agar in that it differentiates between lactose fermenters and

The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.
The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen.
